SENT.plain: A middle aged man presented with abdominal pain and fever, with progressive dyspnea for the past one week
He had generalized lymphadenopathy with hepatosplenomegaly and a left sided pleural effusion on admission
Further evaluation revealed that he had lymphocytosis on peripheral blood
He then developed increasing abdominal pain and fall in hemoglobin which was confirmed on imaging to be due to a splenic rupture and he underwent a splenectomy
The diagnosis on lymph node biopsy and peripheral blood immunophenotyping was grade 1 follicular lymphoma
He has completed his 6 cycles of chemotherapy (R-CVP) and is on maintenance rituximab and doing well
The case highlights the fact that splenic rupture can even be caused by indolent lymphomas
